Context:
The college offers a program with an industry-relevant curriculum delivered through hands-on learning in machine shops, electrical and industrial automation laboratories, process controls and robotics facilities. Students will learn from faculty with experience in both the workplace and teaching environment.

Graduates can expect to find employment in fields such as automation and process control, manufacturing and production, assembly and packaging, building and maintenance of automated systems, power generation and transportation, systems integration, technical sales, and quality control. Industry partners include companies from sectors as diverse as automotive manufacturing, tunnelling and drilling, consumer packaging, food and beverage production, urban transit, power generation, and industrial equipment production and maintenance.

The program consists of the following required courses:

Semester 1: EMNG 1001 (Circuit Analysis), EMNG 1004 (Metrology), MENG 1002 (Engineering Drawing), MENG 1087 (Machining Fundamentals), MENG 1088 (Occupational Health and Safety), GSSC 1027 (Personal Finance), MATH 1160 (Mathematics for Engineering Technology 1), COMM 2000 (Communicating Across Contexts)

Semester 2: EMNG 1003 (Engineering Physics), EMNG 1012 (Introduction to Mechanical CAD), EMNG 1013 (Electronic Devices), EMNG 1015 (Motors & Controls), EMNG 1016 (Electro-Pneumatics), MATH 1171 (Mathematics for Engineering Technology 2), GSSC 1100 (Small Business Plan and Operation)

Semester 3: EMNG 2001 (Introduction to PLC Systems), EMNG 2004 (Digital Electronics), EMNG 2020 (Sensors and Instrumentation), EMNG 2021 (Automation Software Development)

Students enrolling in the program in January are required to complete semester 2 in the summer (May to August) of the same year to continue into semester 3 in the fall. Future study options can be explored through the Transfer Guide.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Electromechanical Engineering Technician Program T146 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
The text provides information about various courses offered in EMNG (Electromechanical Engineering Technology) program at the college under different semesters. Here are some factual information and entities extracted from the text:

* Courses offered under EMNG program: EMNG 2015 (Applied Project), EMNG 2023 (Intermediate Machining), EMNG 2034 (Embedded Systems & Interfacing), EMNG 2040 (Workplace Preparedness & Technical Writing), EMNG 2041 (Robotics), EMNG 3003 (Network Fundamentals)
* General Education Elective: GNED
* Semesters: Semester 4
* Placement test result may require taking COMM 1000 before progressing to COMM 2000.
* Course names and codes for various courses under EMNG program are mentioned.
* Students need to maintain and repair electrical, electronic and mechanical components, equipment and systems to ensure that they function according to specifications and optimize production.
* Students apply, analyze, build, install, commission and troubleshoot a variety of mechanical, electrical and electronic control systems, logic and digital circuits, passive AC and DC circuits, and active circuits.
* Students maintain and troubleshoot automated equipment including robotic systems.
* Students establish and maintain inventory, records, and documentation systems to meet organizational and industry standards and requirements.
* Students select and purchase electromechanical equipment, components and systems that fulfill job requirements and functional specifications.
* Students assist in applying quality control and quality assurance program procedures to meet organizational standards and requirements.
* Students work in compliance with relevant industry standards, laws and regulations, codes, policies and procedures.
* Students develop strategies for ongoing personal and professional development.

Therefore, the extracted information includes the courses offered under EMNG program, their codes, and some of the learning outcomes of the EMNG graduates.

Context:
* The text mentions that the individual is expected to develop strategies for personal and professional development, contribute to engineering team projects, and support project management activities.
* Domestic tuition for programs starting in Fall 2022 is $4,366.00. International tuition for programs starting in Fall 2023 is $17,915.00.
* Students are responsible for purchasing CSA standard safety shoes and prescription safety glasses if needed.
* The program is approved for OSAP funding for eligible applicants.
* Applicants need an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent, with grade 12 English (C or U) and either grade 11 Math (M or U) or grade 12 Math (C or U). Mature students may take the Admissions Assessment for English and math or upgrade their credits.
* The information provided is subject to change without notice and should not be viewed as a representation, offer, or warranty.
* George Brown College fees requirements should be verified by students.

Context:
Applicants should meet minimum requirements but higher grades may be necessary for admission. Course exemptions can be obtained with college or university credits, more information can be found on the Transfer Guide. International students should apply through George Brown College Online Application System and visit the International Admissions page for country-specific requirements. Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges.

Email: engineeringtech@georgebrown.ca
Office hours: 8 a.m. – 4 p.m., room D305
Additional contact options and campus visit information can be found on the Contact Us page.
